text: In Greek mythology, the name Laodocus (; Ancient Greek: Λαόδοκος or Λαοδόκος means "receiving the people") or Leodocus (Λεωδόκος) may refer to: *Laodocus, son of Apollo and Phthia, brother of Dorus and Polypoetes; all three were killed by Aetolus, son of Endymion.Pseudo-Apollodorus. Bibliotheca, 1.7.6 *Laodocus or LeodocusApollonius Rhodius, Argonautica, 1. 119, one of the Argonauts, son of Bias and Pero, brother of Talaus and Areius.Gaius Valerius Flaccus, Argonautica, 1. 358Argonautica Orphica, 149 *Laodocus, a Trojan prince and an illegitimate son of King Priam of Troy.Pseudo-Apollodorus. Bibliotheca, 3.12.5 *Laodocus, son of Antenor. Athena assumed his shape to persuade Pandarus to break the truce between the Greeks and the Trojans.Homer, Iliad, 4. 85 He is possibly the same as the Laodocus killed by Diomedes.Quintus Smyrnaeus, Fall of Troy, 11. 85 *Laodocus, a warrior in the army of the Seven against Thebes, who won the javelin-throwing match at the funeral games of Opheltes.Pseudo-Apollodorus. Bibliotheca, 3.6.4 ==References== Category:Children of Apollo Category:Argonauts Category:Trojans
title: Laodocus
